discussion.author: ppedrot
discussion.comment: No idea. I'd suggest asking on Zulip.

discussion.author: erikmd
discussion.comment:
Hi, thanks for the ping.

The non-availability of coqorg/coq:dev is a known issue (cf. e.g. [this stream](https://coq.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/237663-coq-community-devs-.26-users/topic/coq.3Adev.20Docker.20tag.20currently.20unavailable/near/282503558) on Zulip)

Fixing this is definitely on my backlog, but I won't be able to look after this before Wednesday evening.

In the meantime, you can just replace this line:

https://github.com/fblanqui/color/blob/70f8d37fdaf8c4c973419e0475ccb32020530a30/.github/workflows/docker-action.yml#L21

with:

```yaml
- 'coqorg/coq:dev-ocaml-4.13-flambda'
```

discussion.author: Alizter
discussion.comment:
@fblanqui Unfortunately this one was prepared incorrectly causing some local instances to become global. Another PR will be submitted with a proper patch.

I have no plans to find a backwards compatible solution, but others have discussed this want on Zulip: https://coq.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/237656-Coq-devs-.26-plugin-devs/topic/.5Bdisc.5D.20Make.20hint.20locality.20warning.20an.20error.

commits.author: mattam82
commits.message:
coq-13969 overlay, backwards compatible (speeds up rewrites)
This favors `Equal` over the `Subset` relation when inferring signatures
of morphisms during rewrites, speeding up inference.
An alternative would be to have the equivalence_rewrite_relation instance
unconstrained but that results in a lot more backtracking.

commits.author: maximedenes
commits.message:
Avoid relying on `apply` bug

Sometimes, `apply` accepts to refine existential variables to terms
containing new existentials, which is a bug. We use `eapply` instead.

commits.author: maximedenes
commits.message: Avoid relying on `apply` performing reductions

commits.author: maximedenes
commits.message: Do not rely on unification picking particular non-unique solution

commits.author: maximedenes
commits.message: Help HO unification a bit more

commits.author: VincentSe
commits.message: Put cyclic numbers in sort Set instead of Type

commits.author: jashug
commits.message:
Be robust to a change in the default argument naming algorithm.

Overlay for coq/coq#12756.

This overlay preserves all the old names; the new default names
are just `t` instead of `t0`.

For some context, the old algorithm saw the unqualified name `t`
referring to (apparently) `L.V.XSet.t` and refreshed the argument
names to not conflict, which I don't believe is necessary.

The only exception to this is in `VecArith.v` on `vec_ge_mor`,
where the two sets of arguments `x y` coming from unfolding the
`Proper (... ==> ... ==> ...)` type used to be refreshed into
`x y _ x0 y0 _`, and are now by default the overlapping `x y _ x y _`.
Thus if you want to refer to the second set of arguments in an explicit
application like `vec_ge_mor (x0 := ...)`, they have to be explicitly
renamed as is done here.

discussion.author: Blaisorblade
discussion.comment: Most of this is made obsolete by d5e10eee218116c466dfa878ee3d997abe7ca247, hence closing.

commits.author: Blaisorblade
commits.message:
Fix solution of obligations

Recall that `Next Obligation.` implies `program_simpl` but
`Solve Obligations` doesn't.

However, now this obligation is transparent, which isn't a good idea.

commits.author: Blaisorblade
commits.message:
(Optionally) Reduce breakage to abstraction-breaking clients

Avoid calling `program_simpl` unless `omega` fails, to keep the types of
obligations unchanged.

Not sure this complexity is warranted: well-written client code should be
isolated, but see https://github.com/fblanqui/color/issues/22.

commits.author: Blaisorblade
commits.message:
Make `Vbuild` obligations opaque

In fact, this flag should arguably be unset globally, but that change
requires wider testing and consideration.

discussion.comment: Hi @Zimmi48 . I do not see any result from Travis. Do you know how to get Travis run on your PR?

discussion.author: fblanqui
discussion.comment: Sorry, I found it, but Github doesn't show the result. Do you know what to do on Github to make it show the results of Travis?

discussion.author: Zimmi48
discussion.comment: @fblanqui It seems like a bug of Travis that the status was not reported to GitHub. Many previous PRs did get their CI status reported. Note though that Travis is planning to move away all open source projects from travis-ci.org to travis-ci.com (and the two websites do not report their statuses in the same way). You can request to migrate your repository to travis-ci.com (https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/migrate/open-source-on-travis-ci-com/#existing-open-source-repositories-on-travis-ciorg) and it is likely that it will fix this issue.

discussion.author: fblanqui
discussion.comment:
For Require Import's inside section, I propose to put them at the beginning of the file. Do not split in two pieces: one Require and then one Import.

Why do you remove decidability lemmas on BigZ, etc.? They could be useful, couldn't they?

As for the From Coq/CoLoR's, please keep them to avoid potential name conflicts later.

discussion.author: vbgl
fblanqui
discussion.comment:
Le 23/10/2018 à 08:37, Vincent Laporte a écrit :
>
> Here are some arguments for removing de decidability lemmas on big 
> numbers:
>
>   * this is dead code (never used within the CoLoR library);
>
This is not directly used indeed but is useful if one wants to extract 
CoLoR to OCaml. See http://color.inria.fr/rainbow.html.


>   * this is unrelated to rewriting theory and termination;
>   * if you think these lemmas are of general interest (beyond their
>     non-usage within this library), they should be proposed for
>     inclusion in the |bignums| library;
>
I would be happy if they were included in bignums indeed, like other 
lemmas on lists and vectors for instance. But I currently don't have the 
time to look after that.


>   * the proofs make explicit reference to the |Int31| modules, that I
>     would like to remove from Coq.
>
Ok, but I guess that this would be replaced by something similar or 
moved to bignums, wouldn't it?

discussion.author: vbgl
discussion.comment:
> This is not directly used indeed but is useful if one wants to extract 
> CoLoR to OCaml. See http://color.inria.fr/rainbow.html.

Thanks for the pointer. Unfortunately, I could not find any use of these
lemmas in the code on rainbow. Could you please elaborate on how they
are used? Thanks.

> Ok, but I guess that this would be replaced by something similar or 
> moved to bignums, wouldn't it?
> 

Indeed, the motivation for removing these libraries is the integration
of “primitive integers”: 63-bit machine integers directly available in
the logic. Nonetheless, it would be simpler if third-party libraries did
not directly depend on these libraries.

discussion.author: fblanqui
discussion.comment:

Well, it's no problem: the day this is removed from Coq or bignums, I 
will remove it from CoLoR as well.
